awd_titl_txt: Convergence HTF: RCN: Enhancing Small and Mid-level Farm Viability Through a Systems-based Research Network: Linking Technology and Sustainable Development and Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
This convergence Research Coordination Network addresses the future of work at the human-technology frontier in the context of small- and medium-sized farms. Intelligent, interactive, and highly networked machines -- with which people increasingly interact -- are a growing part of the landscape, particularly in regard to work.  As automation today moves from the factory floor to knowledge and service occupations, research is needed to reap the benefits in increased productivity and increased job opportunities, and to mitigate social costs.  Convergence is the deep integration of knowledge, theories, methods, and data from multiple fields to form new and expanded frameworks for addressing scientific and societal challenges and opportunities. The Research Coordination Network supported by this award will define key challenges and research imperatives at the nexus of humans, technology, and work through the convergence of robotics, human factors, systems and control theory, neuromotor and cognitive sciences, machine learning, systems engineering, data analytics, precision agriculture, ergonomics, health and safety, and sustainability. This project promotes Convergence by exploring methods for incorporating a human-centric focus, including social and economic considerations, throughout the entire technology research and development process.

The specific focus of this Research Coordination Network is to build research collaborations among multiple stakeholders in order to fully realize the potential benefits of emerging technological capabilities in the context of small- and medium-sized farms. The stakeholders include academic researchers with complementary expertise in human factors, robotics, systems engineering, education, and sustainability, among other areas. Small- and medium-sized farms face a variety of serious economic and demographic challenges. Farming is a strenuous and dangerous occupation, which takes a physical toll on an aging workforce. Innovations in automation and robotics may augment individual capabilities as well as reduce the risk of injury, but with these potential benefits come the threat of job displacement and the possible exacerbation of economic inequity. Currently, creation and development of emerging technological solutions are typically driven along parallel, isolated lines of inquiry, with no awareness of the broad and interrelated nature of the issues involved. This research network seeks to provide researchers across relevant disciplines with this integrated perspective, as well as to involve stakeholders in the agricultural community at a much earlier stage in the technology development process.

por.por_cntn:
The HARVEST network functioned along three main themes: embedding technology-development within a human-centered design process; application of a socio-technical systems modeling approach to delineate (and forecast) technology benefits and risks; and facilitation of a lifelong learning network in partnership with university extension programs and local rural rehabilitation networks.

In the first year, virtual meetings of the project's international steering committee were organized, following which, a two-day kickoff workshop was organized in Alexandria VA in May 2018. this workshop included panels in which farmers operating small and medium-sized farm operations on the East and West coasts participated, and discussed resource and market distribution related challenges, technology-driven opportunities such as robotic harvesters, creating desired micro-climates for crops, and vertical farming. This panel was followed by a policy-maker panel that included representatives from the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), Center for Occupational Robotics Research, National Institute of Food and Agriculture (NIFA) and from local farm stewardship organizations. This panel discussed the most significant issues affecting sustainability and productivity, as well as opportunities that could be leveraged by the HARVEST network collaborating with these centers/entities. The second day of the workshop focused on bringing the six disciplines that form HARVEST together in different combinations, to cross-pollinate ideas. Six concrete research questions were identified that would be worked on by standing committees comprised of members of multiple research disciplines.

Two posters were presented at the National Training Workshop (Maine, 2018) of the AgrAbility National project, on the theme of assistive robotics in agriculture. Local farmers from the state of Virginia visited robotics and human-automation interaction laboratories at Virginia Tech, which included their participation in a community approach to develop design specifications of flexible wearable robotic suits. The PIs also hosted high school students in engineering and agricultural education from across the country in several batches (~300 students), for lab visits, career development workshops, and summer schools.

During the second year of the project, based on the themes identified in the kickoff workshop, subgroups embedded within the HARVEST themes organically emerged and pursued several related activities. These included:

(1)    A successful collaboration between robotics, computer science, human factors engineering, social science and economics disciplines in a joint project funded by the Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier. This project was inspired by the application of technology development embedding within a human-centered design framework (HARVEST theme 1) and application of systems thinking for forecasting technology impacts at the individual, peer-to-peer, and social levels (HARVEST theme 2).

(2)    The STEM-education researchers of HARVEST experimented upon, and implemented, innovative curriculum practices for building capacity in agriculture education (disseminated at Virginia Tech).

(3)    A Center for Food Systems and Community Transformation was established in 2019 at Virginia Tech. Directed by a HARVEST PI, this center includes partners from Virginia Tech, Virginia State University, and Virginia Commonwealth University, with the aims of exploring partnership, solidarity and possibility for social equity and sustainability in the local food and farming systems.

The third year of the network involved continuation of virtual meetings of the international steering committee members. Although a 2-day workshop planned for Spring 2020 had to be cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the network participants pivoted towards a virtual seminar series, to maintain participation and engagement. A monthly seminar series with invited speakers in food systems data science and technology, followed by discussions among network participants, was established in Fall 2020. A socio-technical systems approach that considered decision making theory, systems modeling, and human factors evolved during HARVEST discussions, and was applied to solving performance and safety issues in a complex infrastructure system, resulting in a successful international project supported by the NSF LEAP-HI program.

In the next year of the network, activities from previous years were continued, including engagement with the Virginia Beginning Farmer's Coalition and Agrability Virginia. Similar to previous years, another group of HARVEST researchers put together two significant efforts in this year: An NSF convergence accelerator aimed at developing innovative training programs for technology integration; and a transition-to-scale effort for the NSF FW-HTF program. Several ideas about practical industry/end-user challenges and featuring stakeholder concerns early in design processes, understanding technology acceptance from a dual psycho-social and organizational-culture lens, and the importance of rapid prototyping strategies, were born directly out of convergence meetings and discussions within this network.  

Finally, over the lifetime of the network, the numerous inter-discplinary discussions and research among PIs, students, and postdocs led to development of innovative practices for participatory design, team science and collaboration, which the network participants have successfully utilized in student training, promotion of an inter-disciplinary PhD program, as well as for running large convergence-based collaborative projects. The PIs have also engaged actively in science communication and dissemination activities through the HARVEST website, blogposts, conference presentations and visits to federal research and policy making organizations.
